The First World War.passage: The First World War, also known as the Great War, was a global war that began in 1914 and lasted until 1918. More than nine million soldiers, sailors, and airmen, along with over five million civilians, died as a result of the conflict, which is also considered the deadliest war in history. The war was the result of a long period of military, social, and diplomatic tensions between the European great powers before 1914, as well as conflicts between nationalists and imperialists in many other nations. It is also considered a war of choice for Germany and Austria-Hungary, who were hoping to use the conflict as an opportunity to win a war against Russia and France, respectively, as well as knock Russia out of the ongoing conflict in the Caucasus. The war was characterized by mass mobilisation of troops, economic blockades of enemy nations, and trench warfare on the Western Front, culminating in a military stalemate. It was also marked by revolutionary changes in military tactics and technology, including the development of the airplane and the tank. The war drew in all the world’s great powers, which were soon bogged down in a conflict that they were unable to win. The fighting ended with a defeat for the Central Powers, who sued for peace in 1918, and with an armistice for the Allies.

qae_pairs.question: Which year was the first year of the war?
qae_pairs.explanation: The First World War began in 1914.

qae_pairs.question: Which country was the first to use the airplane in war?
qae_pairs.explanation: The first country to use the airplane in war was Germany.

qae_pairs.question: Which country was the first to enter the war?
qae_pairs.explanation: France was the first country to enter the war.

qae_pairs.question: Which country was the home of the Archduke Franz Ferdinand?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Archduke Franz Ferdinand was the heir to the throne of Austria-Hungary. He was assassinated in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, on 28 June 1914, by Gavrilo Princip, a member of the Young Bosnia group. The assassination led to Austria-Hungary's declaration of war on Serbia, which in turn led to a series of events that eventually led to the outbreak of World War I.

qae_pairs.question: What year did the war end?
qae_pairs.explanation: The First World War, also known as the Great War, was a global war that began in 1914 and lasted until 1918.

The Second World War.passage: The Second World War, also known as the Second Great War, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945, although related conflicts began earlier. It involved the vast majority of the world's nations—including all of the great power empires of the time—eventually forming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis. It was the most widespread war in history, and directly involved more than 100 million people from over 30 countries. In a state of "total war", the major participants in the war mobilized their entire economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities to fight it. The conflict led to the deaths of around 50 million people, including around 17 million military personnel. It is also considered the deadliest war in human history, with estimates of the total death toll ranging from 40 to 80 million people, and is one of only two conflicts to have been ranked as the deadliest ever, the other one being the Mongol conquest of the Middle East in the 13th century. World War II can also refer to the era between the end of the conflict and the start of the Cold War, when the Soviet Union and the United States emerged as the two superpowers. The war began with the German invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939, known as "World War II" in Europe, but as "The European War" in the Pacific.

qae_pairs.question: What year did the war start?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Second World War, also known as the Second Great War, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945, although related conflicts began earlier.

qae_pairs.explanation: World War II, also known as the Second Great War, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945, although related conflicts began earlier.

The American Civil War.passage: The American Civil War (1861–1865), also known as the War Between the States, the War of Northern Aggression, and the War of Rebellion, was a major war of the American Civil War that was fought between the Northern states of the United States of America, led by the Republican Party, and the Southern states of the American South, led by the Democratic Party. The war started as a result of the secession of eleven states from the United States following the 1860 presidential election of Republican candidate Abraham Lincoln. The war was fought between the Army of the Potomac, the Army of Northern Virginia, and the Army of Tennessee, commanded by Northern generals, and Confederate armies led by Southern generals such as Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson, and James "P.B." Forrest. The war resulted in the effective dissolution of the United States as an independent nation, with the formation of the United States of America and the Confederate States of America. The American Civil War was caused by the irreconcilable difference between the North and the South over the institution of slavery and the expansion of slavery into the western territories. The war began in April 1861 with the Battle of Fort Sumter and ended in April 1865 with the surrender of Confederate General Robert E. Lee to Union General William T. Sherman.

qae_pairs.question: Which party was in power during the American Civil War?
qae_pairs.explanation: The American Civil War was fought between the Northern states of the United States of America, led by the Republican Party, and the Southern states of the American South, led by the Democratic Party.

The French Revolution.passage: The French Revolution, also referred to as the Revolution of 1789 or the Great Revolution, was a period of far-reaching social and political upheaval in France, lasting from 1789 to 1799, and characterised by violent protests and political upheaval. The Revolution overthrew the monarchy of France (and eventually the monarchies of Spain, Naples, and several other states), established a republic, and unleashed a wave of anti-establishmentarianism and nationalism that spread across Europe.

qae_pairs.question: What continent is the place of the French Revolution?

The Revolution overthrew the monarchy of France (and eventually the monarchies of Spain, Naples, and several other states), established a republic, and unleashed a wave of anti-establishmentarianism and nationalism that spread across Europe.

The Industrial Revolution.passage: The Industrial Revolution was the transition to new manufacturing methods in the late 18th century that transformed economy of the United Kingdom and launched its status as the world's first industrialized country. The transition began in the textile industry and then spread to other industries. It was characterized by a dramatic acceleration in technological innovation, and by the widespread adoption of industrial processes and factory machinery, such as the steam engine, spinning jenny, and power loom. The term "Industrial Revolution" is often used as a shorthand for the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840. However, there were significant technological and social changes that began in the late 17th century and continued into the 19th century. The Industrial Revolution started in Great Britain and then spread to continental Europe and later to North America and Japan. The mechanization of agriculture, the development of new metalworking technologies, and the growth of urban centers were important aspects of the revolution. The period saw a dramatic increase in economic growth and a significant decrease in the price of products, leading to increased consumer wealth and new classes of consumers. The Industrial Revolution began as a response to market forces and the scarcity of skilled labor. The development of machines to replace manual labor was spurred by the Enclosure Acts, which reduced the amount of open land available for grazing and made it profitable for farmers to invest in labor-saving machines.

qae_pairs.question: Which country was the last to industrialize?
qae_pairs.explanation: Japan

qae_pairs.question: Which continent was the first to industrialize?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain and then spread to continental Europe and later to North America and Japan.

qae_pairs.question: Which country was the first to industrialize?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain and then spread to continental Europe and later to North America and Japan.

The Great Depression.passage: The Great Depression (UK)/The Great Depression (US), also known as the 1930s Depression or the Depression of the 1930s, was a severe worldwide economic depression that began in 1929 and lasted until about 1939. The timing of the Great Depression's beginning varies by country; in most of Europe, it started in 1930, and lasted for several years. The Great Depression was the longest, deepest, and most widespread depression of the 20th century. It is commonly held to have been the longest, deepest and most widespread depression of any type in the history of mankind, although the severity, duration, and impact varied widely by country and region. In terms of the percentage of GDP, the Great Depression was the deepest and longest lasting depression of the 20th century. The Great Depression is considered by many economists to have been the worst economic crisis of all time, prior to the 2008 global financial crisis.

qae_pairs.question: Which year did the Great Depression start?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Great Depression started in 1929.

qae_pairs.question: Which century did the Great Depression last?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Great Depression lasted from 1929 to 1939.

The Russian Revolution.passage: The Russian Revolution, also known as the October Revolution, 1917 Revolution, or the Bolshevik Revolution, was a historical event that began on 7 November (25 October, Old Style) 1917 and culminated in the overthrow of the Russian monarchy and the establishment of a socialist state. It was the culmination of a long period of political and economic upheaval in Russia, during which the country had been in the process of moving away from an agrarian, pre-industrialized economy towards an urban, industrialized society. The Russian Revolution also marked the defeat of Tsarism and the end of 3 centuries of Romanov rule. The immediate cause of the Revolution was Russia's involvement in World War I. Russia had been one of the Great Powers since its defeat of Napoleon in 1815, but it was not prepared for a modern war. The war and its disastrous effects on the economy, combined with political turmoil and the poor leadership of Tsar Nicholas II, led to the Revolution. In the words of historian Richard Pipes, "the Revolution was the work of a coalition of diverse groups, but it was the common people who did the fighting". The immediate catalyst for revolution was the February Revolution, which began in Petrograd, then the Russian capital, on 24 February 1917 (6 February, Old Style). This revolution overthrew the Tsar and his government, but it did not lead to the establishment of a republic.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Russian Revolution was the culmination of a long period of political and economic upheaval in Russia, during which the country had been in the process of moving away from an agrarian, pre-industrialized economy towards an urban, industrialized society.

The Nazi Party Takes Control.passage:
The Nazi Party Takes Control
In 1933, the Nazi Party (German: "Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei" / "NSDAP") under Adolf Hitler came to power in Germany, and quickly established a dictatorship. The NSDAP had campaigned on a nationalist, anti-communist, and anti-capitalist platform. Hitler and the Nazis pursued an aggressive foreign policy, starting with the remilitarization of the Rhineland and the annexation of Austria in March 1938 and the Sudetenland in September 1938. The remilitarization of the Rhineland violated the Treaty of Versailles, which had ended World War I and had required Germany to withdraw its troops from the Rhineland. In March 1939, Germany annexed the largely ethnically-German Sudetenland from Czechoslovakia. The annexation was a violation of the Munich Agreement, in which Britain, France, and Italy had promised to protect the Czechs if Germany invaded. The Munich Agreement had also allowed Germany to annexe the rest of Czechoslovakia if it invaded. The annexation was a violation of the Munich Agreement, in which Britain, France, and Italy had promised to protect the Czechs if Germany invaded
In September 1938, Germany had signed a non-aggression treaty with the Soviet Union.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Soviet Union signed a non-aggression treaty with Germany in September 1938.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Sudetenland was annexed by Germany in 1938, which was a violation of the Munich Agreement, which had allowed Germany to annexe the rest of Czechoslovakia if it invaded.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Sudetenland was annexed by Germany in 1938.

The Nazi Party Takes Control of Germany.term: The Nazi Party Takes Control of Germany
The Nazi Party Takes Control of Germany.passage:
The Nazi Party Takes Control of Germany
After the Nazis' poor showing in the 1928 elections, Hitler was appointed chancellor on 30 January 1933, and took the title of Führer und Reichskanzler ("leader and chancellor"). The Reichstag fire on 27 February was used as a pretense for passing the Enabling Act of 1933, which gave Hitler the authority to rule by decree. The Act was passed with a two-thirds majority, and the Reichstag building was then burned down. The Nazis used this as a pretext for the establishment of the first concentration camp at Dachau, which was opened the same day as the Reichstag. Hitler's cabinet, known as the Cabinet of Hindenburg, was composed of members of the Nazi Party (NSDAP), the German National People's Party (DNVP), and the German Workers' Party (DAP). Hitler appointed Wilhelm Frick as the new Minister of the Interior and Hermann Göring as the new Minister of the Prussian Interior. Göring, as the leader of the SA, became the de facto leader of the brownshirts, and Frick became the de facto leader of the SS. Hitler's half-aunt, Margarethe "Gertrud" Hänsel, who lived in Vienna, was appointed as the new Minister of Education.

Germany.passage: Germany (i/ˈdɛrməgi/; German: Deutschland [ˈdɔʏtʃlant] (listen)), officially the Federal Republic of Germany (German: Bundesrepublik Deutschland [ˈbuːntsʁɛpɐʁliːt ˈdɔʏtʃlant] (listen)), is a federal parliamentary republic in central Europe. It includes 16 constituent states while its capital and largest city is Berlin. With about 82.8 million inhabitants, Germany is the fourth most populous country in Europe after France, Russia, and Italy. Germany covers an area of 357,386 square kilometers (137,913 sq mi) and has a largely temperate seasonal climate.

France.passage: France (i/fɑːrˈʁaɪn, fəˈrɑːn, -rən), officially the French Republic (French: République française), is a country with territory in Western Europe, and several overseas regions. France has the most people and the second-largest area of any European country, and the second-most land area in the European Union after the United Kingdom. It has some overseas territories in the Americas, Asia, and Africa, as well as more than one thousand dependent territories and regions. France's population is estimated to be about 66 million, the highest of all European countries. The territory of France is one of the largest in Europe, with an area of, and a significant population of 51 million. The area of France is approximately the same as the area of Italy. France borders Belgium to the northwest, Germany to the west, Switzerland and Italy to the southwest, and Andorra and Spain to the southeast. The territory of Metropolitan France, including the island of Corsica, covers, making it the twelfth largest country in the world.

Austria-Hungary.passage: Austria-Hungary ( or ), also known as the Austro-Hungarian Empire ( /, ) was an Austro-Hungarian empire founded in the late 15th century that lasted until the aftermath of World War I. The empire originated as a union of the crowns of the Kingdoms of Bohemia, Croatia, Hungary, and of the lands of the former Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia, joined by the Crown of Saint Stephen, a personal union of the Kingdoms of Croatia and Hungary under a single ruler.

the United States.passage: The United States is a country in the New World. It is sometimes referred to as the USA (United States of America) or the US (United States). It is made up of 50 states (plus Washington DC, the capital) and a federal district (the District of Columbia), which is the seat of government of the US. It is bordered by the Pacific Ocean to the west; the Mexican state of Chihuahua to the southwest; the Mexican state of Sonora to the northwest; the Canadian province of British Columbia to the north; the Atlantic Ocean to the east; Bermuda to the northeast; and the Caribbean Sea to the southeast.

Abraham Lincoln.passage: Lincoln's mother died of milk sickness in 1818, and his stepmother Sarah Bush died in 1835. He was raised by his father, who remarried in 1829 to another woman named Nancy Hanks. She raised Lincoln and his younger sister Sarah. Lincoln was born to a family of modest means in a one-room log cabin, but the Lincolns were not in want. The family moved several times, and by the time Lincoln was nine his father had accumulated 300 acres (121 ha) of land and several head of livestock. Lincoln received only a small portion of his education in a one-room "blab school" in a log cabin, taught by a young local resident named Dennis Hanks. Lincoln received his only formal schooling at age 16, when he enrolled at the newly opened Springfield (Illinois) "Sangamo" Academy. Lincoln's formal education ended after one year, as his family could not afford to keep him there. Lincoln taught himself how to be a surveyor and acquired a reputation as a skilled practitioner. He became a licensed land surveyor, and he earned a living surveying land for others. Lincoln also developed an ability to read and interpret legal documents. He became a Whig (a political party opposed to the expansion of slavery into the western territories), and he developed a reputation among his fellow party members as a skilled orator.

Tennessee.passage: Tennessee is a Southern state in the southeastern United States. Tennessee was admitted to the Union on June 1, 1796, having been the last of the original 13 colonies to do so. Tennessee was the last state to leave the Union and join the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Robert E. Lee.passage: Robert Edward Lee (September 3, 1807 – October 12, 1870) was an American soldier and military strategist. A native of Stratford Hall, Virginia, Lee was a career United States Army officer and a graduate of West Point. As a young man, Lee resigned from the U.S. Army in 1831 to join the United States Corps of Engineers. He resigned from that service in 1853, and returned to the U.S. Army in time to participate in the Mexican–American War. He was promoted to the rank of brigadier general and commanded a brigade in the Army of Northern Virginia. He was known for his leadership of the Army of Northern Virginia during the American Civil War. Lee surrendered the Army of Northern Virginia at the Appomattox Court House, and his forces were the last to surrender. He was paroled and allowed to return home. He died 16 years later, on October 12, 1870, and was buried at Lee Chapel at Washington and Lee University.

Napoleon.passage: Napoleon I (French: [noˈpɛlɑ]; Italian: [ˈnɔplaˈɲo]; born Napoleone di Buonaparte; 14 January 1769 -- 5 May 1821) was a French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and went on to rule the French Empire as its Emperor from 1804 until his final defeat at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. He is considered one of the most successful military commanders in history, and his reign is often referred to as the "Age of Napoleon". After a series of victories on the battlefield, Napoleon took control of France and much of the surrounding territory, and ruled as a military dictator. He created a new political structure called the Consulate, and held a series of political meetings with other European leaders known as the Congress of Vienna. He integrated new technology and ideas into the military, and expanded the size of the army. He reorganized the government bureaucracy, and created a new system of education that emphasized the values of the Revolution. He pursued an expansionist foreign policy that aimed to challenge the British Empire and the Russian Empire, but was defeated in the War of 1812, and later the conflict with Russia became a personal vendetta. Napoleon's rule has often been described as an empire, but historians have debated its nature and characteristics. Napoleon's government was autocratic, with little tolerance for opposition.

the Soviet Union.passage: The Soviet Union (Russian: Советская Страна, tr. Sovetskaya Soyúza, lit. "Soviet Union"; IPA: [ˈsʉvʲet͡sɨkə ˈsotɕɪkvə ˈsotɕɪŋə]) was a country that existed from 1922 to 1991. A Marxist–Leninist state with a centrally planned economy, the Soviet Union was a totalitarian state characterized by a hierarchical structure of social classes, strict social and cultural norms, and state-controlled mass media. The Communist Party, headed by a secretariat and Politburo, was the ruling party of the country. The Soviet Union had a developed industrial infrastructure, and was one of the world's major nuclear powers. The Soviet Union was the first state to develop a large-scale nuclear weapons programme and possessed the largest stockpile of nuclear weapons, with an estimated total of between 20,000 and 60,000 warheads. It invaded three neighboring countries, China, Korea, and Vietnam, between 1939 and 1991, and had a military presence in Eastern Europe and in Africa. The Soviet era was preceded by the Russian Empire, which was founded in 1721 and collapsed in 1922.

qae_pairs.question: What was the year of the collapse of the Soviet Union?

qae_pairs.explanation: The Soviet Union was the successor of the Russian Empire.

Czechoslovakia.passage: Czechoslovakia (Czech and Slovak: Československo, Slovak: Česko-slovenská republika; Czech and Slovak: Československo, Slovensko; Slovene: Češkoslovenští, Češko-slovenská republika; Slovak: Československo, Slovensko; Slovak: Češko-slovenská republika; Slovene: Češko-slovenština, Češko-slovenska republika), also known as Czechoslovak Socialist Republic (ČSSR), was a state that existed from October 1918, when Czechoslovakia was founded, to December 1992, when the state was split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia. The official name of the state was the Republic of Czechoslovakia until January 1, 1993, when it was changed to the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic. The Czech and Slovak Federative Republic (ČSFR) was a federation of Czechoslovakia and the First Czechoslovak Republic from October 1918 to October 1938.

The Sudeten Germans are a German ethnic group, and are a sub-group of the German people who inhabit a region of the Czech Republic and Germany that has traditionally been known as the Sudetenland, a historical region of Bohemia, or the Sudetes mountain range in the Central European Highlands.

The Nazi Party.passage: The Nazis (German: National-sozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei; NSDAP), commonly referred to as the Nazis ( /ˈnætsi/; /ˈneɪtsi/; NATIONAL SOCIALIST German ARMY), officially the German National Socialist Workers' Party (German: Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei), commonly referred to as the NSDAP ( /ˈnæsəˌspeɪt/; /ˈnæsəˌspeɪtʃə/), abbreviated as NSDAP ( /ˈnæsəˌspeɪtə/; /ˈneɪʃəˌspeɪtə/), or shortened as N.S.D.A.P. ( /ˌniːˌsɛsəˈdɑːp/), was a far-right political party in Nazi Germany that was the ruling and largest party of Germany from 1933 to 1945. The Nazi Party originated in 1919 as the German Workers' Party (German: Deutsche Arbeiterpartei; DAP), founded by Anton Drexler. The DAP was renamed the National Socialist German Workers Party (NSDAP) in February 1920, and became the Nazi Party in 1925.

Adolf Hitler.passage: Adolf Hitler (German: [ˈadɔlf ˈhɪtlɐtɐ]; 20 April 1889 – 30 April 1945) was a German politician who was the leader of the Nazi Party (NSDAP), Chancellor of Germany from 1933 to 1945, and Führer (Leader) of Nazi Germany from 1934 to 1945. Hitler was a decorated veteran of World War I. After his service in the German Army, he worked as a low-level official in the Nazi Party, rising through the ranks to leader. Hitler was the leader of Nazi Germany from 1933 to 1945, and the main architect of the Holocaust.

Hermann Göring.passage: Hermann Göring (German: [ˈɡɔːrɪŋ]; 9 September 1893 – 23 February 1946) was a German military officer and politician who was the second-highest-ranking member of the Nazi Party (after Adolf Hitler) until his arrest and conviction for crimes against peace at the Nuremberg Trials. Göring was one of the principal leaders of the Nazi regime, serving as the first Minister of Aviation, the second-highest-ranking official in the Reich Cabinet, and commander-in-chief of the Luftwaffe (German Air Force). Göring was also the second-highest-ranking official in the Nazi Party after Hitler. Göring was a recipient of the Knights Cross of the Iron Cross, the highest military decoration in the German Reich. He and Hitler led the Nazi Party in its transformation from a political movement into a mass-based authoritarian party during the 1930s, taking advantage of economic and social tensions resulting from the Great Depression and the German re-militarisation after the Nazi Party came to power in January 1933. Göring's power and influence grew throughout the early 1930s, as he became the de facto leader of the Nazi Party, while Hitler concentrated on consolidating power and preparing for his own totalitarian state.

qae_pairs.explanation: Hermann Göring was a recipient of the Iron Cross, the highest military decoration in the German Reich.

Dachau.passage: Dachau was founded in 1933 by the Nazi Party (NSDAP) as a concentration camp. The first prisoners, communists and social democrats, came from jails in the Bavarian town of Dachau, hence the name. The first commandant was Theodor Eicke, a career soldier and war criminal. The camp was initially set up in buildings confiscated from a Jewish community.
